expectations:
- MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese (teaching Japanese)
      - Should include dedicated chapters for writing systems (hiragana, katakana, kanji)
      - Should cover Japanese-specific grammar (particles, verb forms, honorifics, counters)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes and communication scenarios

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model D is exceptionally comprehensive with ~140 chapters covering A1 through C2. It excels in several areas: (1) Writing systems are well-covered with dedicated chapters for hiragana, katakana, and multiple kanji chapters at different levels, plus ortography chapters. (2) Grammar coverage is outstanding - it breaks down grammar into very granular, specific chapters (e.g., separate chapters for each conditional type たら/なら/ば・と, separate chapters for each て-form compound like ておく/てしまう/てみる/てある/ていく・てくる). (3) Vocabulary and communication scenarios are well-integrated throughout. (4) Japanese-specific features like keigo (split into multiple chapters), transitivity pairs, counters, particles, onomatopeias are all covered thoroughly. (5) Descriptions are concise and to the point, avoiding fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. (6) No forbidden chapter types (no skill-based, culture, career, exam prep, or literature chapters). (7) The progression is natural and logical, interleaving grammar and vocabulary chapters. (8) Advanced topics like ambiguity/disambiguation, register variation, archaisms, and discourse markers are covered. Minor issues: some chapters might be overly granular (e.g., separating を particle into its own chapter), and some descriptions could be slightly more concise. The chapter on 'Ordem de traços & escrita manual' in Model B but not here is a non-issue since this model covers ortography. Overall, this is the most thorough and well-structured curriculum.

Model C is very comprehensive with ~90 chapters. Strengths: (1) Hiragana and katakana are split into 3 parts each, which is pedagogically sound for such complex writing systems. (2) Multiple kanji chapters at different levels. (3) Good grammar coverage including Japanese-specific structures (particles, te-form, keigo, causative-passive, conditionals, etc.). (4) Vocabulary themes well-covered (food, health, transport, clothing, etc.). (5) Good progression from beginner to advanced. (6) Descriptions are generally concise and informative. (7) No forbidden chapter types detected. Issues: (1) 'Trabalho e Profissões' could be seen as borderline career/professional, though it's listed as a vocabulary theme in the prompt's examples so it's acceptable. (2) The last chapter 'Fluência e Expressão Natural' is somewhat vague and could be seen as a skill-based chapter. (3) 'Gramática Avançada 1' and 'Gramática Avançada 2' are somewhat generic titles that don't specify content domains clearly. (4) Some chapters like 'Gramática de Maestria 1/2' are catch-all chapters rather than specific content domains. Overall very solid but slightly less granular than Model D in grammar breakdown.

Model A provides ~61 chapters with good coverage. Strengths: (1) Good writing system coverage (hiragana, katakana, three levels of kanji). (2) Japanese-specific grammar is well-covered (keigo split into three chapters, causative-passive, conditionals, particles). (3) Descriptions are concise and well-written, following guidelines. (4) Good interleaving of grammar and vocabulary. (5) No forbidden chapter types. (6) Advanced topics covered (onomatopeias, literary structures, idioms). Issues: (1) Could be more comprehensive - 61 chapters may not cover 'everything' from A1 to C2 as thoroughly as needed. Some vocabulary themes are missing or underrepresented (e.g., no dedicated chapter for work/occupations, no money/finances chapter). (2) 'Artes e Entretenimento' could be borderline culture/literature, though it focuses on vocabulary. (3) Some gaps in grammar coverage compared to Model D (e.g., no dedicated chapter for transitivity pairs, comparatives/superlatives, nominalizers). (4) The progression is good but could benefit from more intermediate-level chapters. Overall a solid curriculum but less comprehensive than Models D and C.

Model F has ~95 chapters with good coverage. Strengths: (1) Writing systems covered (hiragana, katakana, three kanji levels). (2) Grammar is broken down well with good granularity. (3) Japanese-specific features covered (keigo, causative-passive, counters, particles, onomatopeias). (4) Good vocabulary coverage. (5) Descriptions are generally concise. Issues: (1) Some chapters seem somewhat skill-based or too abstract: 'Narrativa e Storytelling', 'Descrição e Explicação', 'Naturalidade e Fluência', 'Refinamento e Precisão de Alto Nível', 'Pragmática Avançada' - these feel more like skill-based chapters than content domains. (2) 'Elipse e Inferência Contextual' is borderline skill-based. (3) Kanji chapters are placed very late (chapters 71-73) which seems odd for a language that requires kanji early. The hiragana/katakana placement is fine but kanji fundamentals should appear much earlier. (4) Some chapter titles like 'Idiomática e Colocações' are awkwardly worded. (5) The ordering could be improved - having kanji so late disrupts the natural progression. These issues prevent it from scoring higher despite good breadth.

Model B has ~71 chapters. Strengths: (1) Writing systems covered well with multiple kanji chapters including radicais. (2) Good grammar coverage including keigo, particles, conditionals. (3) Vocabulary themes are present. (4) Onomatopeias and idioms covered. Issues: (1) 'Ordem de traços & escrita manual' is borderline skill-based (writing practice). (2) 'Lecturas de kanji: on/kun' uses Spanish word 'Lecturas' instead of Portuguese - this is a factual/language error for a Portuguese curriculum. (3) 'Arte & música' could be borderline culture. (4) 'Formas arcaicas & histórico-linguísticas' mentions 'literatura e documentos antigos' which touches on forbidden literature territory. (5) 'Procedimentos legais & administrativos' is borderline career/professional. (6) Some descriptions use forbidden fluff words or aren't as concise. (7) 'Registro falado vs. escrito' is somewhat skill-based. (8) The 'Lecturas' error is notable as it should be 'Leituras' in Portuguese. Overall decent but has more rule violations than other top models.

Model E has only ~48 chapters, making it the least comprehensive. Strengths: (1) Writing systems covered (hiragana, katakana, multiple kanji levels). (2) Basic Japanese grammar structures covered. (3) Descriptions are generally concise. Issues: (1) Only 48 chapters is insufficient for A1-C2 comprehensive coverage. Many important topics are missing or merged. (2) 'Voz Passiva e Causativa' combines two major grammar topics into one chapter - the prompt explicitly asks for separate chapters. (3) 'Maestria e Fluência Nativa' is a vague, skill-based chapter that doesn't specify content domains. (4) 'Estilos de Escrita e Registros Formais' is somewhat skill-based (writing skills). (5) Missing many vocabulary themes (no dedicated money/finance, no travel/hotel, no directions chapter). (6) Missing important grammar areas (no dedicated chapter for comparatives/superlatives, no transitivity pairs, limited conditional coverage). (7) Many chapters are too broad (e.g., 'Gramática Avançada e Nuances' is too vague). (8) The keigo coverage is split into only 2 chapters which is insufficient. (9) No dedicated counters chapter beyond basic counting. This is the least comprehensive curriculum and has notable gaps.

Model D provides an absolutely flawless curriculum that strictly adheres to all constraints. It perfectly captures the nuances of Japanese grammar, vocabulary, and pragmatics across 108 highly detailed chapters. Crucially, it successfully teaches advanced C2 Japanese grammar (like ぬ/ず/まい/べからず) without ever violating the 'NO literature or media' constraint, cleverly framing them as 'Registro elevado na língua moderna'. It includes zero skill-based chapters, zero culture/media chapters, and its titles and descriptions are exceptionally concise, descriptive, and free of fluff. An outstanding output.

Model F also provides an excellent curriculum that respects all negative constraints. It successfully avoids any mention of literature, media, or skill-based chapters (like reading or writing practice). The progression is very logical and the coverage of Japanese grammar is thorough. The only minor weakness compared to Model D is that a few of the final advanced chapters have slightly fluffy titles (e.g., 'Naturalidade e Fluência', 'Refinamento e Precisão de Alto Nível') instead of focusing explicitly on the linguistic structures being taught.

Model A has a solid progression and covers Japanese grammar well, but it explicitly violates negative constraints. The prompt explicitly forbids media and literature chapters. However, Model A includes a chapter on 'Artes e Entretenimento' mentioning 'cinema' (media), and a chapter on 'Estruturas Gramaticais Literárias' that explicitly focuses on 'textos jornalísticos ou literários densos' (news media and literature). These violations incur a heavy penalty.

Model B provides a comprehensive curriculum but violates several negative constraints. It includes a chapter on 'Formas arcaicas & histórico-linguísticas' that explicitly mentions 'literatura e documentos antigos', violating the 'NO literature' and 'NO culture (history)' rules. It also includes an 'Ordem de traços & escrita manual' chapter which leans towards writing practice/skills, which are supposed to be integrated automatically rather than given their own chapters.

Model C suffers from multiple significant violations of the prompt's negative constraints. First, it violates the 'NO skill-based chapters' rule by including a chapter on 'Leitura e compreensão de kanji' (Reading comprehension). Secondly, it violates the 'NO literature or media' constraint multiple times by including 'Expressões Literárias e Arcaicas' (textos clássicos) and 'Política e Sociedade' (notícias/news media).

Model E violates the negative constraints and features fluffy descriptions. It includes a chapter on 'Estilos de Escrita e Registros Formais' that explicitly teaches 'literatura clássica' and 'notícias' (news), directly violating the 'NO literature or media' rules. Furthermore, its titles and descriptions are less granular and more prone to fluff (e.g., 'Maestria e Fluência Nativa') compared to the top models.

Extremamente completo e bem granular, com progressão clara do básico ao avançado, forte cobertura de gramática japonesa (partículas, aspectos com ている/てしまう/ておく/てある, condicionais, voz passiva/causativa, keigo em camadas), pragmática/discurso (marcadores, implicatura, coesão), e capítulos de escrita (kana e kanji) sem cair em “pronúncia/leitura/escrita” como habilidade geral. Também evita cultura, mídia, exames e carreira. Pequenas escolhas de título como “Ortografia em hiragana/katakana” ainda são conteúdo (convenções de escrita) e aceitáveis dado o foco em sistemas de escrita do japonês.

Muito forte em cobertura e progressão, com boa mistura de domínios (gramática, cenários, vocabulário) e capítulos dedicados a hiragana/katakana/kanji. Excelente bloco avançado de pragmática/registro/coesão/sintaxe. Porém não há tanto detalhamento específico de kanji (p.ex., níveis/leituras/componentes) quanto D, e alguns títulos/descrições ficam um pouco amplos/abstratos (“Descrição e Explicação”, “Sintaxe Complexa”) em vez de amarrar a construções japonesas específicas. Ainda assim, cumpre as restrições e é de alta qualidade.

Cobertura ampla e geralmente precisa, com capítulos dedicados a hiragana/katakana/kanji e muito conteúdo avançado (partículas, condicionais, keigo, voz, registros). Bom equilíbrio com temas de vocabulário e cenários. Problemas: inclui capítulo explicitamente proibido (“Artes e Entretenimento” — literatura/mídia/entretenimento). Também há alguns tópicos que tangenciam cultura/conteúdo não prioritário (provérbios/yojijukugo podem ser aceitáveis como idioma, mas “Artes e Entretenimento” não). Menos granular em alguns pontos iniciais do que poderia.

Bem estruturado, com boa progressão e capítulos separados para hiragana/katakana/kanji. Forte em gramática central (partículas, te-form, condicionais, voz, registros) e vocabulário cotidiano. Porém viola regras importantes: inclui capítulos de carreira/profissão (“Trabalho e Profissões”) e também conteúdo de “notícias/atualidades” no título/descrição de política/sociedade (mídia). Além disso, “Kanji em Contexto: jornais, artigos...” encosta em mídia/literatura. Alguns títulos como “Subjuntivo” são inadequados para japonês (conceito não mapeia diretamente), e há temas potencialmente fora do escopo/arriscados (jurídico) embora não seja “carreira”.

Cumpre o básico (kana/kanji, partículas, formas verbais, condicionais, voz, keigo) e inclui temas de vocabulário. Mas tem granularidade insuficiente para um currículo “o melhor do mundo” (muitos capítulos genéricos/aglutinados) e viola diretamente restrições: “Família e Ocupações” entra em trabalho/profissional, e “Estilos de Escrita e Registros Formais” menciona “notícias” e “literatura clássica” (mídia/literatura proibidas). Também usa descrições um pouco vagas e por vezes com tom de “introdução”.

Boa cobertura de gramática (partículas, formas, keigo, discurso) e muitos temas de vocabulário/cenários. Contudo viola regras de forma clara: inclui capítulo de carreira (“Trabalho & ocupações”). Inclui também capítulos que se aproximam de habilidades/áreas proibidas (“Ordem de traços & escrita manual” é treino de escrita/caligrafia; além de “Apresentações & oratória” soa como skill-based). Há ainda idioma misturado/erro (“Lecturas de kanji” em espanhol) e itens discutíveis como “Formas arcaicas & histórico-linguísticas” (parece capítulo de linguística/história, próximo de “histórico”, embora não seja cultura explícita).
